questions.question: What is the primary characteristic of time series data?

options.A: Data points are independent of each other.
options.B: Data points are recorded at regular or irregular intervals over time, and the order of the observations is important.
options.C: Data represents cross-sectional snapshots at a single point in time.
options.D: Data consists of categorical variables only.

questions.question: What are the main components often decomposed in time series analysis?

options.A: Features, labels, and noise.
options.B: Trend, seasonality, and residuals (or noise).
options.C: Mean, variance, and autocorrelation.
options.D: Frequency, amplitude, and phase.

questions.question: What is the 'trend' component in a time series?

options.A: Short-term fluctuations in the data.
options.B: A long-term increase or decrease in the level of the time series.
options.C: Repetitive patterns occurring at fixed intervals.
options.D: Random, irregular variations in the data.

questions.question: What is 'seasonality' in a time series?

options.A: A long-term direction of the data.
options.B: Repetitive patterns that occur at fixed time intervals (e.g., daily, weekly, yearly).
options.C: Sudden, unexpected events in the data.
options.D: The average value of the time series.

questions.question: What are 'residuals' (or 'noise') in time series decomposition?

options.A: The trend and seasonality components combined.
options.B: The long-term increasing or decreasing pattern.
options.C: The repetitive seasonal fluctuations.
options.D: The irregular or random fluctuations remaining after the trend and seasonality have been removed.

questions.question: What is autocorrelation in time series analysis?

options.A: The correlation between different time series.
options.B: The correlation of a time series with a lagged version of itself.
options.C: The trend component of the time series.
options.D: The seasonal component of the time series.

questions.question: What does the Autocorrelation Function (ACF) plot show?

options.A: The trend and seasonality of a time series.
options.B: The correlation between a time series and its lagged values at different lag orders.
options.C: The distribution of the time series data.
options.D: The frequency components of the time series.

questions.question: What is the Partial Autocorrelation Function (PACF) plot?

options.A: The autocorrelation between different time series after removing the effect of intermediate lags.
options.B: The direct correlation between a time series and its lagged values, removing the influence of the intermediate lags.
options.C: The moving average of the autocorrelation function.
options.D: A smoothed version of the ACF plot.

questions.question: What is a stationary time series?

options.A: A time series with a clear trend.
options.B: A time series with strong seasonality.
options.C: A time series whose statistical properties (mean, variance, autocorrelation) do not change over time.
options.D: A time series with no fluctuations.

questions.question: Why is stationarity often important in time series modeling?

options.A: Non-stationary time series are easier to model.
options.B: Many time series models assume stationarity for their theoretical properties to hold.
options.C: Stationary time series always have better forecasting accuracy.
options.D: Stationarity is only relevant for visualization.

questions.question: What are some common methods for making a non-stationary time series stationary?

options.A: Averaging, smoothing.
options.B: Differencing, detrending, deseasonalizing.
options.C: Scaling, encoding.
options.D: Clustering, dimensionality reduction.

questions.question: What is the Autoregressive (AR) model?

options.A: A model that predicts future values based on a linear combination of past errors.
options.B: A model that predicts future values based on a linear combination of past values.
options.C: A model that forecasts based on weighted moving averages of past observations.
options.D: A model that incorporates the seasonal component of the time series.

questions.question: What is the Moving Average (MA) model?

options.A: A model that predicts future values based on past values.
options.B: A model that predicts future values based on a linear combination of past error terms.
options.C: A model that forecasts using a weighted average of past observations.
options.D: A model that accounts for the trend in the data.

questions.question: What is the Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA) model?

options.A: A simple average of past values.
options.B: A model that combines autoregressive (AR), differencing (I for integrated), and moving average (MA) components to model non-stationary time series.
options.C: A model that only considers seasonal patterns.
options.D: A model that is only used for stationary data.

questions.question: What do the p, d, and q parameters represent in an ARIMA(p, d, q) model?

options.A: p: order of moving average, d: degree of differencing, q: order of autoregression.
options.B: p: degree of differencing, d: order of autoregression, q: order of moving average.
options.C: p: order of autoregression, d: degree of differencing, q: order of moving average.
options.D: p: period of seasonality, d: trend order, q: noise order.

questions.question: What is the Seasonal Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (SARIMA) model?

options.A: An ARIMA model applied to deseasonalized data.
options.B: An extension of ARIMA that explicitly models the seasonal component of a time series.
options.C: A simple moving average model for seasonal data.
options.D: An autoregressive model applied only to the seasonal part of the data.

questions.question: What are some common evaluation metrics for time series forecasting?

options.A: Accuracy, precision, recall.
options.B: Mean Squared Error (MSE), Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE).
options.C: R-squared, adjusted R-squared.
options.D: Silhouette score, Davies-Bouldin index.

questions.question: What is the train-test split approach typically adapted for time series data?

options.A: Randomly splitting the data into training and testing sets.
options.B: Splitting the data chronologically, with earlier data used for training and later data for testing to preserve the temporal order.
options.C: Using cross-validation folds that are shuffled.
options.D: Training on the most recent data and testing on earlier data.

questions.question: What are some applications of time series analysis?

options.A: Image classification and object detection.
options.B: Natural language processing tasks like sentiment analysis.
options.C: Forecasting stock prices, weather patterns, sales figures, and energy consumption.
options.D: Clustering customer data based on demographics.

questions.question: What are some challenges specific to time series analysis and forecasting?

options.A: Dealing with high dimensionality.
options.B: Handling non-stationarity, seasonality, irregular patterns, and the dependence on the order of observations.
options.C: The lack of large datasets.
options.D: The difficulty in interpreting model parameters.
